section.title: Tuple Values
section.para: Orc's Tuple data type is a sequence of at least two values. (Orc does not provide for the construction of "0-tuples" or "1-tuples".)
Tuples are intended to be used for sequences with a fixed length and varying element types, whereas lists are intended to be used for sequences with varying length and a fixed element type.
One can explicitly project a tuple element by its index, but it is idiomatic, safer, and far more common to use pattern matching to extract tuple elements.

section.title: Constructors
section.para: A tuple is written as two or more expressions, separated by commas and enclosed within parentheses. Execution of the tuple expression (e_1, ..., e_n) deflates each ei to a value vi and publishes the tuple value (v_1, ..., v_n).

section.title: Operations
section.para:
Notable tuple operations include:
Projection: tuple( index )
Project first element of pair: fst
Project second element of pair: snd

section.title: Java calls
section.para: Orc Tuples don't correspond to any Java value, so if a Tuple is passed to Java code, it will be as a java.lang.Object of a type not specified here.

example.title: Tuple Selection
example.programlisting: {- Unzip a list of tuples into a tuple of lists. -} val squares = [(1,1), (2,4), (3,9), (4,16)] ( map(fst,squares) , map(snd,squares) )

example.title: Fork-Join
example.programlisting: {- Print "fork", but wait at least 500ms before printing "join" -} ( println("fork"), Rtimer(500) ) >> println("join")
